entry.title: Enhancing Safety and Efficiency – How SAP S/4HANA Transforms Dangerous Goods Management
entry.content:
Managing dangerous goods in today’s global supply chains is not only about meeting regulations, it plays a key role in keeping people safe and protecting the environment while also making sure business operations keep running smoothly. Manual processes or disconnected systems can quickly lead to delays, mistakes, and unnecessary risks.

SAP S/4HANA for Product Compliance and its Dangerous Goods Management capabilities can close this gap. By simplifying and automating dangerous goods processes instead of relying on spreadsheets or outdated information, companies can handle their dangerous goods confidently and efficiently without slowing down their operations. Product Compliance comes with embedded regulatory content like UN classifications, hazard labels, shipping names, and transport permissions. So, with that, products can be classified correctly and handled safely throughout the entire supply chain.

What for me really stands out is the integration into everyday business processes. The system automatically calculates and checks transport permissions and flags missing or incomplete classification data. This stops non-compliant shipments before the products leave the warehouse. With built-in analytics, teams can gain a clear overview of regulatory requirements, which makes it much easier to act proactively.

What the video is about:

  • How SAP S/4HANA simplifies classification and global transport management for dangerous goods
  • How embedded regulatory content supports safety and compliance
  • How automated checks and documentation reduce errors, delays, and manual work
  • How analytics provide transparency across the supply chain

This topic is specially close to me because safety and compliance belong together. When they’re built into daily processes and supported by automation, they don’t slow teams down. They actually make work easier while reducing risks and building trust across the organization and beyond.

SAP Video - In brief: SAP Product Compliance - Dangerous Goods

Watch the video to see how SAP S/4HANA for Product Compliance can help your organization handle dangerous goods safely and turn regulatory requirements into a real advantage.

entry.title: Filtering records based on measure value when copying data via Data Action in SAC
entry.content:
Dear Community
I have a planning model in SAC called Merge, which is built by merging data from many planning models, one of them is a model called HR (containing employee information).

Currently, I use Data Actions to copy data from the source models into the Merge model. For the HR model, the data is loaded via an Upload Job (every month) and then transferred to the Merge model using a Data Action.

However, in the Merge model I only need employee records where the measure IST is not null / not equal to 0. 
Therefore, when copying data from the HR model into the Merge model, all records where IST = 0 should be excluded. In other planning scenarios I need all data in HR model, so I cannot simply delete it at source.

All involved models share two public dimensions: Cost Center and Company Code.

The challenge is that when copying data from one model to another via a Data Action, filters can only be applied to dimensions, not to measures (at lest to my knowledge). Unfortunately, I don’t see a way to create a calculated dimension in the planning model that could be used for filtering (for example: if IST = 0 then Exclude = X).

I already tried the following workaround:

  • Create an intermediate model (HR_NEW) using a Data Action:

  • First, copy the relevant data from the HR model
  • Then, delete the records where IST = 0:
    IF RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "IST") = 0 THEN
    DELETE()
    ENDIF
  • Use this intermediate model (HR_NEW) as the data source for the Merge model

This solution works only as long as the intermediate model has no public dimensions, which makes it unusable in my case.

Does anyone have an idea how these HR data (excluding IST = 0) could be transferred correctly into the Merge model?

Thanks in advance for any suggestions!
Wiola

@N1kh1l @Chris1973

entry.title: Bulk Download Of Payslips - SAP Payroll
entry.content:
Introduction :

Ever Wondered if there was a Way to download Payslips of Employees in Bulk? Well, It is Possible with Spool Requests. Compensation Team always find difficult to download Payslips of employees one by one for Backup /Audit Requirements.

Here's the Breakdown of Configurations to achieve this!

 Access the Transaction HRFORMS and Choose the Custom / Standard Pay slip that is being Used

Double Click on the Form and open in Change Mode

Click on the Selection Screen Tab and Check the Number of Employees per Form and Save and Activate the Form

On the Top Left Corner , Click Form -> Print Program (Test)

Specify the Number of Employees You want to be downloaded in Bulk in One form and Save as Variant

Access the Transaction PC00_M99_CEDT_MULTIP

Choose the Payroll Area , Payroll Period and navigate to the Report and Variant

 

Choose HRFORMS

Enter your Country Grouping , Form Name and Variant

Before Executing the Creation of Payslips , Make sure the User does not have default output device set as LP01 and Print Now should be Disabled.

The Bulk Payslip should be created as a Spool Request which can be viewed from SP02.

View the Spool Request from SP02 and Click on Overall View on , All the Payslips will merged into One File and it can be downloaded.

Pro Tip :

You can split the PDF and rename it with Employee ID - Employee Name by using Third-Party Tool Sejda.

Conclusion:

The Following Configuration was done as a part of requirement from one of the leading banks in Bahrain and Client was super happy about the Bulk Download of Payslips and with Sejda things have got even better where they were able to save it using ID - Name with just a click of a Button. Features like this really improve the operational efficiency and saves a lot of time and Man Power.

entry.title: Re: Step-by-Step Guide to Data Migration Cockpit in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
@alex_alf 
it always depends on the complexity of an object template (number of sheets and fields that you must fill out), the number of records and the number of systems you need to import this. The more fields you need to enter and the more systems you need to import that data, the more it make sense to enter this within the migration template and then upload the data.

As cost and profit center are from low complexity it is probably faster to enter the single cost center and profit center manually instead of filling the template and then upload them via the cockpit. We internally say that for business objects with less than 20 instances per migration into a system, it makes no sense to create a migration object as the effort to create an object is much much higher, than entering the data manually.
Hope that helps.

BR
Frank

P.S. It is better to ask such questions in Q&A area and not as a comment within a blog.

entry.title: Re: 'Starting new task' process is not send to sp01
entry.content:
So basically you execute in a RFC call some code such as (From code in the called transaction, depends on the actual ok_code) 

    AUTHORITY-CHECK OBJECT 'F_NFBA'
       ID 'ACTVT' FIELD '35'.
    " raise error and exit if failure
    SUBMIT RSNAST00 AND RETURN
      WITH S_KAPPL = 'NF' " Nota Fiscal
      WITH S_OBJKY = <DOCNUM>...

So you could

  • Add some list options parameters  to the call and handle error messages?
  • Check also (or force) some parameters such as dispatch time and the like.

entry.title: Uwaga, uwaga! SAP Business Network supports your e-invoicing compliance in Poland
entry.content:
Countries around the globe are steadily moving towards mandatory e‑invoicing. As we head into 2026, multiple new mandates are set to roll out. Poland is among the next in line: the mandate becomes effective in February 2026 for large companies and in April 2026 for medium to small companies (excluding microbusinesses). The mandate requires them to issue, send, and receive domestic electronic invoices in the country format FA3_VAT. The invoices need to be digitally signed by the suppliers, timestamped by the KSeF​ tax portal, and need to be stored for a minimum of 10 years. The invoice mandate applies to all VAT established companies in Poland​.

SAP Business Network's strategy commits to remaining compliant in countries rolling out e-invoicing regulations. For Poland, the details of the technical setup and the configurations steps are listed in below checklist.

Your checklist as a supplier on SAP Business Network

SAP Business Network will facilitate compliance by converting invoices to the mandated format and clearing them with the tax portal, reducing errors and speeding up processing and payments. This means that trading partners on SAP Business Network can continue to use the portal (PO Flip) and their integrated solutions in compliance with Poland's e-invoicing requirements.

Suppliers must configure their country settings on their SAP Business Network account and ensure their customers can receive tax invoice documents in the required format:

  1. Create you Country Configuration on SAP Business Network and provide the required information. This is necessary to clear the invoice with KSeF Portal on behalf of the supplier. Detailed instructions can be found in this guide. 
  2. Verify if your customer has enabled the rule “Require suppliers to send tax invoice documents” for Poland, ensuring your invoices are issued in the required FA3_VAT format. ​The trading partner guide shows you where you can check for the activation on this rule.
  3. All Integrated suppliers are required to include mandatory tax exemption details for zero value VAT entries. ​
  4. The legal invoice needs to be archived for at least 10 years by both buyer and the supplier. Using SAP Business Network long term archiving is optional, you can use the archiving solution of your choice. For more information on SAP Business Network’s long-term archiving options, click here.

In addition to the guide, we encourage your to access the on-demand webcast for more details to support you in your invoicing journey, including downloadable resources: Replay: SAP Business Network - Support of the Invoice Mandate in Poland

To keep exploring our response to e-invoicing mandates as well as other resources on maximizing your account usage, head over to our SAP Community page.

entry.title: Re: Fetching deleted records in Integration center
entry.content:
Hi rezadwi

  1. In MDF, make the standard field mdfSystemStatus editable.
  2. In Dependents, create a custom field named status with values Active/Inactive.
  3. Configure a business rule in Dependents so that instead of deleting a record, its status is set to Inactive.
  4. In Integration Center (IC), map:
    • The status field in Dependents
    • The mdfSystemStatus field in MDF
      This ensures that records are marked as Inactive rather than deleted.

entry.title: Connecting SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud with Microsoft PowerBI using OAuth2.0
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community,

I am trying to establish a connection between SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud and Microsoft Power BI using OAuth2.0 as the authentication method. I am using the standard communication scenario SAP_COM_0053, which according to the documentation supports OAuth 2.0. The connection is set up via an OData Feed in Power BI. However, I am unable to get the “Organizational Account” sign-in option working in Power BI.

Errors encountered

  • Power BI Desktop:
    “The WWW-Authenticate header doesn't contain a valid authorization URL.”
  • Power BI Service (Cloud):
    “Failed to login with OAuth token. Please try logging in again.”

Additional context

  • I previously created a custom communication arrangement using Basic Authentication, which works without any issues.
  • Our Dev and Test tenants use SAP Profile Management (SSO via SAP Identity Authentication Service).

Question
Has anyone successfully connected Power BI directly to SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud using OAuth? If so:

  • Are there specific prerequisites or configuration steps required?
  • Is SAP IAS officially supported for OAuth authentication with Power BI?
  • Is this a known limitation of Power BI’s OAuth implementation?

Any insights, confirmations, or recommended approaches would be highly appreciated!

Kind regards,

Mike van Ingen
Finance

entry.title: Re: sap analytics cloud
entry.content: In SAP Analytics Cloud Modeler there is no support for doing table joins like in a database, because SAC models are designed to consume already prepared data, so joins must be done in the source system such as SAP BW, SAP Datasphere, SAP HANA, or during data preparation while acquiring data, and once the model is created SAC can only work with dimensions and measures and not perform relational joins.

entry.title: Re: Trying to get YTD with 1 month offset SAP Analytics C...
entry.content: In SAP Analytics Cloud this cannot be achieved using a single restricted account range because offset based ranges always cross year boundaries by design, so you cannot limit the calculation strictly from January to the previous month within the same filtered year, and this is a system limitation rather than a scripting issue, so the correct approach is to create two separate restricted measures, one fixed YTD from January to the selected month and another YTD from January to one month before using a time offset with an additional year filter or variable in the model or source, and then use these two measures in the waterfall chart to compare Jan to previous month versus Jan to selected month.

entry.title: What is planned for the 2602 release of SAP Variant Configuration and Pricing?
entry.content:
The 2602 release of SAP Variant Configuration and Pricing is planned to be deployed to BTP customer tenants on January 21, 2026:

Administration UI and Administration service:

Release

Test/Non-Productive & Productive Upgrades

2602

January 21, 2026

Variant Configuration service & Pricing service:

Release

Test/Non-productive Upgrade

Productive Upgrade

2602

January 21, 2026

February 11, 2026

 

This blog covers the following planned innovations:

  • Configuration and Pricing Services – Root Certificate Change
  • Configuration and Pricing Services – Deprecation of /closeSession
  • Pricing service – Ability to mark items as price relevant
  • Pricing service – Ability to use “condition update” feature to limit discounts
  • Pricing service – Ability to use data determination at the access level (KDATU)
  • Pricing service – Integration with SAP Ariba Contracts
  • Variant Configuration service – Ability to search configurations by knowledge-base ID

It also includes a call to act regarding the following changes:

  • Configuration and Pricing Services – Root Certificate Change
  • Configuration and Pricing Services – Deprecation of /closeSession

 

Please check the updated roadmap and release notes after the release date to see which of these features were delivered as planned.

and they should not be relied upon in making purchasing decisions.

 

Configuration and Pricing Services – Root Certificate Change

As announced in the previous release blogs, the root certificates on SAP BTP are planned to be updated in Q1 2026. For more details and the exact timelines in January see the SAP Note 3566727. See also SAP BTP Cloud Foundry: switching to higher securit... - SAP Community.

Action: Calls to configuration and pricing services
This is a breaking change for calling the configuration and pricing services. Please verify whether your landscape, from which SAP Variant Configuration and Pricing is called, is already supporting the new root certificate, especially if you are using custom integrations. This is due on the dates mentioned in the SAP Note 3566727.

Action: Data replication with SAP HANA smart data integration (SDI)
On HANA Cloud, a cross-signed certificate which supports the old and new one will be used during a transition period. Please upgrade the SDI DP Agent to version 2.8.0.2 or higher or follow the workaround of the SAP Note 3617329.  
All SAP Enterprise Cloud Services (ECS) / RISE customers have been informed via a top issue. See also the SAP Note 3622538.

In the administration UI of SAP Variant Configuration and Pricing users are currently seeing the following warning message:

DP Agent Notification

 

This message appears even if you have already imported the new certificate and will only disappear 24 hours after the DP agent upgrade. This message will be removed again at the end of February.

 

Configuration and Pricing Services – Deprecation of /closeSession

The endpoints POST /closeSession of the configuration and pricing services used to be used to remove configurations and pricing documents from the HTTP session. This is no longer required because of improved resource management.

The endpoints were set to be deprecated and will be removed with the release 2605.

Action: If called from your application, remove those calls before the May release next year (2026).

More information was published with the 2025 May release in the API definition of the Pricing service and the Variant Configuration service and in the Development Guide (Pre-Production).

 

Pricing service – Ability to mark items as price relevant

We will introduce a new flag for the item input structure that allows items to be explicitly marked as relevant for pricing or not relevant for pricing. If the flag is not set, the item is automatically treated as price relevant.

This will be done for both, stateless and document pricing.

Items marked as not relevant for pricing will be persisted with the pricing document, but they will be skipped during price calculation.

Stateless Pricing

Document Pricing

More information will be published with the February release in the API Definition and the Development Guide (Pre-Production).

 

Pricing service – Ability to use the condition update feature to limit discounts

If the condition update feature is enabled for a condition type in the back end, the system will track how often a condition record is used in sales orders and updates the corresponding entries in the table S071 in the back end. See also Tracking Cumulative Values With Condition Update | SAP Help Portal.

Pricing service will add limited support for the condition update flag (KOUPD): If the flag is set, the pricing engine will read the maintained value from the condition record and will ensure that the current discount does not exceed the limit when combined with the entries in table S071.

This functionality will not be supported for group conditions.

Support for S071 only includes:

  • Project-based replication from the back ends SAP ERP or S/4HANA Private Cloud, but not possible for S/4HANA Public Cloud
  • No standard replication
  • Entries must be filled by back-end processes
  • No maintenance of data in S071 from the Pricing service or on SAP BTP

For example, a customer may receive a 2% discount for a specific material, up to a maximum cumulative discount value of USD 1,000. As the customer continues to place sales orders for this material, the back-end system keeps track of how much discount has already been consumed and updates this information in table S071.

During pricing, the Pricing service reads the consumption values from S071 and evaluates whether the maximum value defined in the condition record has been reached. Once the cumulative discount consumption hits the maximum limit (in our example USD 1,000), the system stops applying the discount.

In the condition response, the flags maximumValueExceeded and/or maximumBaseExceeded are set to indicate that the limit has been reached.

max limits indicators

More information will be published with the February release in the API Definition and the Development Guide (Pre-Production).

 

Pricing service – Ability to use data determination at the access level (KDATU)

Pricing service will support data determination at the condition access level through the field KDATU (Pricing Date) with access type C – Data Field from Condition Table.

Let's suppose you want to offer customers in a specific customer group the prices from the previous year. These prices are no longer valid in the current year, but for this group, you want the system to evaluate pricing using a historic pricing date—for example December 31 of the previous year.

To achieve this, the pricing date must first be determined separately and then applied during pricing. A data-determination condition type such as PBUD is used for this purpose.

The condition type PBUD is configured with an access sequence that contains the field KDATU.

The following table explains access sequence PBUD with the following access:

Field

Name

Processing Type in Access (Field AType)

KDATU

Pricing date

C (data field for data determination)

The PBUD access reads a customer-specific condition record that returns the required pricing date—for this example, 12/31 of the previous year. This retrieved date is stored internally during pricing as the data determination value.

Once the pricing date was determined by PBUD, it can be used during the evaluation of subsequent pricing conditions.

To apply this data:

  1. Add both PBUD (for determining KDATU) and the relevant discount condition type—for example KXXX—to the pricing procedure.
  2. Assign requirement routine 202 to the discount condition type KXXX.
  3. Requirement 202 instructs the pricing engine to:
    • Read the previously determined KDATU value, and
    • Use that value as the effective pricing date for evaluating KXXX.

As a result, the discount KXXX is processed as if the pricing date was 12/31 of the previous year, allowing prior-year prices or discounts to be granted even though they are no longer valid under the current pricing date.

The following table summarizes the setup in the pricing procedure:

Condition Type

Purpose

Requirement

PBUD

Data determination (retrieves pricing date KDATU)

–

KXXX

Uses the determined date for pricing

202 (applies the pricing date from PBUD)

The engine’s calculation trace will be enhanced to show the overwritten pricing date for a pricing routine.

In the condition determination trace, check the field StepTimeStamp to see which date is used for the access.

In the pricing results, the item condition response structure successfulAccess will be enhanced to not only return the relevant passed pricing attributes but also the attributes like KDATU that were determined during the access:

Item Condition Response

The interface for local and remote extensions will be enhanced, in that way: a custom routine can request the successfulAccess structure as input, so that the overwritten KDATU from a condition in the preceding step can be received as input and the pricing date KOMK-PRSDT can be overwritten in the routine’s response structure accessDateList:

Extensions Trace

More information will be published with the February release in the API Definition, the Development Guide (Pre-Production), and the Extension Guide (Pre-Production)

 

Pricing service – Integration with SAP Ariba Contracts

Enable SAP Ariba Contracts to use the Pricing service in purchasing scenarios.

For that, we will work with a predefined pricing procedure that does not have to be replicated from a back end. We will enable the contracts app to create condition records for that pricing procedure and to use them for pricing.

The integration is planned to be released in Q1 2026. Please check for announcements by SAP Ariba.

 

Variant Configuration service – Ability to search configurations by knowledge-base ID

We will introduce the knowledge-base identifier kbId as additional filter criterium for the endpoint GET /api/v2/externalConfigurations:

Search for Configurations

This can be used to check if a certain knowledge-base runtime version is still used to decide if it can be deleted in the back end.

More information will be published with the February release in the API Definition and in the Development Guide (Pre-Production).

 

With that, you have a good overview of what innovations are planned for the February release. Please check the updated roadmap and release notes after the release date to see which of these features were delivered as planned.

entry.title: How do we join and delta data through the datasphere system and out to an external system
entry.content:
We want to be able to stage and join SAP S/4 data through datasphere and into an external system.

This would involve creating some kind of view (lets say joining PO Item and PO History), adding logic and business semantics, and then passing out to an external system. 

So far so good. But we only want to pass changes to the data. Not full loads. 

The 2 CDS views covering this data trigger deltas independently of each other so we cant send the view every time 1 CDS triggers as the other may not have triggered. So in my eyes, we need to persist the joined up view and then send out changes. How is this handled. In BW this would have been staged to a common table (DSO) and this would have detected changes to the joined up data and passed it out of the system

We seem to have gone backwards here !? there seems to be no delta mechanism???

 

thanks -

entry.title: QR- Bill Process from SD Invoice to FI Clearing via CAMT53.001.04
entry.content:
QR Invoices Switzerland: QR Reference Printing and Clearing via CAMT.053 / CAMT.054

I am currently working on the implementation of Swiss QR invoices and would like to clarify several conceptual and technical points regarding QR reference handling and automatic clearing via electronic bank statements.

What I want to achieve

The goal is twofold.
First, QR references should be printed correctly on outgoing customer invoices in Switzerland.
Second, incoming payments should be cleared automatically using CAMT.053 and or CAMT.054 files.

Current system situation

QR control data is maintained for the QR IBANs. The customer number is not filled, as this is not mandatory, but otherwise the relevant QR invoice customizing has been completed.

However, the FI accounting document does not contain any QR reference in field KIDNO.

Regarding incoming payments, the CAMT.053 bank statement refers to an IBAN that is not the QR IBAN to which the customer actually transfers the money. Concretely, we have one bank with two accounts: a standard CHF account and a separate QR account (CHFQR). The customer pays to the QR IBAN (CHFQR), but in SAP the payment appears on the CAMT.053 of the normal CHF account. There is no CAMT.053 file provided for the QR IBAN itself. This raises the question whether this setup is correct from a banking and SAP perspective, or whether a separate bank statement per IBAN should be provided by the bank.

Additionally, according to SAP Help documentation, accounting documents in Swiss company codes should contain country specific fields. (Like f.e. the QR Reference: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/918bca53037f408f91a2295d04ac16bc/7f570997dcc04312a30b5a066fca7460.html) These fields are not available in our system. The CoCd is CH01

Questions regarding clearing logic

Is it mandatory that the QR reference is stored directly in the FI document in order to enable automatic clearing, for example in field KIDNO? If yes, is additional logic required for this, such as a BAdI or user exit? (GLO_SDBIL_KIDNO_CHANGE maybe but I can only see that it is usually für Direct Debits)

Alternatively, is automatic clearing also possible if only a “normal” reference is stored in the document? Based on my understanding of the QR invoice customizing (QR control data), SAP should be able to decompose the QR reference into its components and derive the relevant reference data for clearing, provided the customizing is correct.

Dunning process question

The dunning process also generates its own QR reference. This QR reference will most likely not be stored directly in the original FI documents. On which basis does SAP know which open items are paid when a payment with this QR reference is received? Where is this reference technically stored, and in which tables? Is automatic clearing via a dunning QR reference supported by standard SAP logic?

Questions related to Electronic Bank Statement processing

Is it required to process both CAMT.053 and CAMT.054 files, or is one of them sufficient for QR invoice clearing?

 

Any clarification on standard SAP behavior versus required enhancements would be highly appreciated.

entry.title: From Insights to Action: Process Excellence by Combining Process Mining, Task Mining & Automation
entry.content:
In today’s enterprise landscapes, most companies already have plenty of process data, tactical insights – and automation tools used; what’s often missing is a clear path from insight to action. Today, we will discuss how this gap can be closed using SAP Signavio, KYP.ai (SAP Partner), and SAP Build (including Joule Studio).

This post recaps and explains the storyline of the Devtoberfest session, including the demo:

This blog post is a joint work with @ManuelTae - Manuel Taechl (SAP Signavio), Jakub Lutter and Piotr Wisniewski (both: KYP.ai – SAP Partner).

 

About SAP Signavio

SAP Signavio solutions help companies connect strategy to execution and increase business agility. In use at more than 3,000 global customers, the SAP Signavio Process Transformation Suite strengthens collaboration across business and IT, providing a clear map of how work gets done, which operational systems underlie that work, guidance on potential improvements, and the ability to model and assess the impact of any changes on customers and employees. By giving companies the ability to discover, understand, benchmark, improve, and transform their business processes, SAP Signavio accelerates the journey to digital transformation, operational excellence, and customer centricity. 

About KYP.ai, an SAP Partner (SAP Store listing)

KYP.ai is a Productivity Intelligence Platform that provides end-to-end visibility into how work gets done across people, processes, and technology. By combining data from digital footprints, business systems, and hardware, it uncovers inefficiencies, measures productivity objectively, and enables organizations to drive automation, performance, and engagement improvements across their operations.

KYP.ai is a cloud-based SaaS platform that gives enterprises end-to-end visibility into how work is actually done across people, processes, and technology. By continuously mining operational data from business systems and digital footprints, it identifies inefficiencies, bottlenecks, and opportunities where automation or AI can create value - helping organizations improve productivity, optimize workflows, and align operations with business objectives.

The value proposition centers on four major dimensions: uncovering “where” work happens, understanding “who” does it, seeing “how” processes and technology are used, and defining “what” needs to change to improve outcomes. By doing this, the platform helps organizations reduce manual effort, accelerate execution, improve engagement and drive business results such as margin improvement or cost-reduction.

About SAP Build

SAP Build is SAP's unified low-code and pro-code toolkit that empowers developers, IT professionals, and business experts to collaborate on creating applications and automating workflows. Built on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), the platform combines intuitive visual, drag-and-drop tools with intelligent AI assistance, enabling rapid deployment compared to traditional development. By integrating with SAP Signavio and KYP.ai, organizations can translate process insights into solutions while preserving their clean core architecture.

The approach combining visual development with optional pro-code customization allows SAP Build to handle both simple tasks and complex cross-system scenarios.

SAP Build recently introduced Joule Studio, a new solution that enables customers to create custom skills and AI agents for Joule, SAP's generative AI co-pilot, opening possibilities for intelligent automation and decision support.

 

The Big Idea: Connect Three Worlds

  1. Process mining (SAP Signavio Process Intelligence) reveals how core processes actually run in backend systems.
  2. Task & productivity mining (KYP.ai, SAP Partner) reveals what people really do on the frontend – across apps, screens, and tools.
  3. Automation & AI (SAP Build Process Automation + Joule Studio) turn those insights into executable & actionable workflows and AI skills.

Instead of stopping at “here’s the bottleneck,” we go through a full loop:

  • Discover issues on a process level
  • Analyze tasks affecting processes at more tactical level (e.g. desktop tools used)
  • Identify automation candidates
  • Build and deploy automation scenarios
  • Expose them as reusable Joule skills to be used with Joule, SAP’s generative AI co-pilot
  • Measure ROI and improve continuously

High-level view:

 

Step 1: Understand the Process with SAP Signavio

The story starts where many transformation programs begin: with SAP Signavio.

Using Signavio Process Intelligence, the team ingests event logs from core transactional systems (for example, order-to-cash, purchase-to-pay, or shared-services workflows) and builds a digital twin of the process.

Signavio reveals things like:

  • Where cases get stuck (bottlenecks and long waiting times)
  • Rework loops and deviations from the happy path
  • Variants by region, business unit, or system

This is backend-centric: it shows what is happening inside the transactional systems, based on event logs and timestamps. That is incredibly valuable to get the full & detailed picture of the process. What can we add to that? It doesn’t fully explain why users behave as they do at the desktop level and what happens in tools which we don't analyze with process mining (e.g. Microsoft Outlook or Excel).

That’s where KYP.ai, an SAP Partner, comes in.

 

Step 2: Go Deeper with Task Mining via KYP.ai

KYP.ai complements SAP Signavio by looking at the frontend and user interactions:

  • Which applications employees switch between
  • How long they spend in each window
    • Identifying patterns for improvement based on copy-paste work, manual data entry, or repetitive clicks
  • How much time is idle or lost in context switching

While SAP Signavio answers:
“What does the process look like in the system?”

KYP.ai complement the answer:
“What are people actually doing on their screens to make this process happen?”

This combination can be used to:

  • Start from a problematic process area identified in SAP Signavio
  • Then zoom into individual tasks and micro-activities that make up that step
  • Quantify automation & agent proliferation potential based on volumes, repetition, and complexity

This is crucial for AI and automation: many of the best use cases live in fragmented, manual, cross-application work that backend logs alone cannot fully represent.

 

Step 3: Identify High-Value Automation Opportunities

Once both levels of insights are available, the team can prioritize automation candidates:

  • Tasks that occur frequently
  • Tasks that follow a repeatable pattern
  • Tasks that are error-prone or time-consuming
  • Tasks spanning multiple systems (SAP and non-SAP)

This outlines how task-level analytics from KYP.ai help filter for “big automation potential” tasks, not just any repetitive activity, while also turning the conversation with business stakeholders into something much more concrete:

  • “This step costs X hours per week.”
  • “Automating it could free Y FTEs or reduce processing time by Z%.”

After opportunity identification and assessing the potential, we continue with the ground work for setting the stage for implementation. By using the data that we collected, we leverage the KYP.ai Concierge, an AI-powered assistant, to generate prompts for the agent building. These prompts define the role, workflow, integrations and actions documents needed to build the automation or the AI agent.

At this point, the story moves from analysis to execution.

 

Step 4: Create Process Automation scenarios with SAP Build

With clear candidates in hand, we shift to SAP Build on SAP Business Technology Platform.

Using SAP Build, developers and business technologists can:

  • Model approval flows and automations, both on the API and UI level
  • Integrate with SAP systems through prebuilt connectors, as well as non-SAP systems
  • Orchestrate human tasks and system tasks
  • Develop AI skills and custom Joule Agents (planned) with Joule Studio

Users can benefit from low-code, as well as

  • Instead of starting from a blank canvas, developers describe in natural language
    what the automation scenario should do
  • The tooling proposes a flow, which can then be refined, configured, and hardened
  • In our case, we are able to leverage the prompt that was generated by KYP.ai on the previous step.

This shortens the time from idea → prototype → tested flow and makes it much easier to iterate as more data from process and task mining comes in.

 

Step 5: Operationalize as Joule Skills and Agents

The last step is how to operationalize what has been built so that it can be:

  • Reused across different processes
  • Triggered by users through natural-language interaction with Joule, SAP’s generative AI co-pilot

This is where Joule Studio enter, allowing us to wrap automations and workflows as Joule skills – self-contained capabilities that Joule can call.

  1. Use Joule Studio to define when and how these skills are used:
    • The goal of the agent
    • The tools/skills it can call (including Build automations)
    • Guardrails and policies for safe execution
  2. Expose those agents to end-users via SAP Fiori, SAP Start, SAP Work Zone, or other entry points.

Instead of a disparate process mining dashboard and a automation tool, there is a continuous improvement loop where:

  • Joule can detect a scenario (e.g., “many open items over threshold”)
  • Decide which skills to call
  • Execute workflows built in SAP Build as part of the skills
  • And write back outcomes into SAP systems, all under IT governance.

 

Step 6: Measure and improve continuously

Close the loop: Measure the impact of your automations, convert improvements into business value, and feed results back into process and task mining to prioritize the next cycle.

  • Use SAP Signavio to establish baseline KPIs and calculate the monetary potential of fixing the identified issues.
  • Drill into user-level detail with KYP.ai to validate root causes, quantify impact, and construct the prompt/spec for the SAP Build automation.
  • Build and deploy the automation in SAP Build, then wrap it as Joule skills/agents
  • Re-measure the same KPIs in SAP Signavio after deployment, convert improvements into realized monetary value, and publish results to stakeholders.
  • Use those validated results as a flywheel and secure stakeholder buy-in to prioritize the next set of opportunities and accelerate the next improvement cycle.

 

Why This Matters for Developers and Automation Teams

For developers, solution architects, and automation COEs, as well as process analysts, process owners and general set of business stakeholders, the session illustrates a few important shifts:

  • From point tools to an ecosystem
    Signavio, KYP.ai, SAP Build, and Joule Studio are not isolated. They reinforce each other: insight → design → automation → execution.
  • From one-off bots to governed, reusable capabilities
    Instead of scripting ad-hoc automation tasks, the approach encourages building managed automations and Joule skills that sit inside a governed SAP BTP environment.
  • From generic AI hype to measurable outcomes
    Using KYP.ai to detect AI and automation opportunities at task level helps ensure AI is applied where it has clear, quantifiable impact.
  • From manual interpretation to data-driven prioritization
    Combining process mining and task mining means decisions on where to automate are backed by hard data – not just stakeholder opinions.

 

How to Apply This Approach in Your Own Landscape

This is something developers can replicate in their own environment. A practical way to start:

  1. Pick a single business process
    Something with clear pain: order management, invoice handling, onboarding, or service requests.
  2. Run process mining with SAP Signavio
    Ingest event logs, build the process model, and identify the biggest delays and rework loops.
  3. Layer task mining with KYP.ai
    Focus on the most problematic steps. Capture desktop activity for a representative group of users and let KYP.ai highlight where time is really spent.
  4. Align with business and automation stakeholders
    Review the top 3–5 opportunities based on volume, feasibility, and expected impact.
  5. Prototype & create executable process automation scenarios in SAP Build
    Use prompt-based design to scaffold automations, then refine integrations, exception handling, and approvals.
  6. Wrap and scale via Joule skills and agents
    Add the most successful automations as Joule skills, so they can be called from natural-language interfaces and reused across teams.
  1. Measure, prove and iterate
    Use Signavio to capture baseline and post-deployment KPIs, publish these proof points to secure buy‑in, and use them as a flywheel to prioritize the next cycle.

 

This integrated approach offers a pragmatic way to move from dashboards and analysis toexecutable automation and AI, powered by process & task insights, in our daily work.

It is less about any single tool and more about connecting insights to action in one continuous loop.

Thank you for your interest and please share your thoughts in the comments!

 

Related materials for further reading:

From Process Mining to Productivity Intelligence and Transformation

Enterprise Automation with SAP

KYP.ai SAP Store listing

entry.title: Accelerate Your Lead-to-Cash Cycle: Seamless SAP CPQ Quoting from SAP Sales Cloud V2
entry.content:
In the competitive world of Lead-to-Cash, a streamlined workflow for managing quotes is no longer a luxury—it's the foundation for sales teams to hit their targets faster. When speed and accuracy matter, moving from Opportunity to Quote should be instantaneous. With the use of out of box integration between SAP Sales Cloud V2 and SAP CPQ, sales team can now initiate quote creation without ever leaving the familiar environment of the Sales Cloud V2 Opportunity screen (Guided Selling).

In this blog, I will explain some key aspects of the Quote integration from SAP Sales Cloud V2 to SAP CPQ, covering the key prerequisites and steps to set up the integration.

What This Integration Means to the end users:

Sales team can now leverage key features of sales quotation management directly from the SAP Sales Cloud V2 Guided Selling screen:

  • Direct Quote Creation from Opportunity object: Initiate an SAP CPQ quote directly from an existing opportunity in Sales Cloud V2. Customer and context data are transferred automatically, eliminating manual data entry and speeding up the sales cycle.
  • Seamless, Embedded CPQ Access: Launch the robust SAP CPQ quoting interface right from within Sales Cloud V2. With SSO enabled, you can access CPQ instantly without the need entering credentials.
  • Real-Time Data Consistency: Forget manual updates. Product quantities and final quote values are automatically synced back to the related Sales Cloud V2 opportunity in real-time, ensuring your pipeline data is always accurate and consistent.
  • Clean & Efficient API-Driven Architecture: Uses direct API communication between Sales Cloud V2 and SAP CPQ, with no shadow quote creation in Sales Cloud V2 — reducing redundancy and improving efficiency

Typical Use Case of CPQ Quotation from Sales Cloud V2

Initiating the Quote in Sales Cloud V2 Opportunity

The journey begins, naturally, in SAP Sales Cloud V2.

  • A user creates a new Opportunity, capturing essential details like customer information and sales context.
  • The user populates the Opportunity with initial Products and specifies the desired quantities. This sets the foundation for the quote.
  • To launch the formal quotation process, the user selects the External Sales Quote option.

This action instantly triggers the creation of a follow-up quote in SAP CPQ, powered by the standard content within SAP Cloud Integration.

Seamless Navigation and Pre-filled Data

Once the quote is generated in CPQ, the Sales Cloud V2 Opportunity is immediately updated.

  • The newly created CPQ quote is visible directly within the Opportunity's Sales Quote section.
  • The user can seamlessly navigate to the full CPQ quoting interface by simply clicking the quotation hyperlink. This smooth transition is enabled by the External Link configuration in Sales Cloud V2.
  • Zero data entry is required for the initial quote. The CPQ quote screen is pre-filled with all the details pulled from the opportunity: products, quantities, and initial estimated prices.

Real-Time Synchronization and Data Consistency

As the quote matures in CPQ (pricing, configuration, discounting), the two systems remain perfectly synchronized:

  • Document Flow Update: The quote ID is instantly added to the Opportunity's Document Flow, providing a clear audit trail.
  • Real-Time Data Flush & Fill: As you update the quote in CPQ, a real-time synchronization pushes key data points—such as the quote status and discounts—back to the Sales Cloud V2 Opportunity.
  • Instant Financial Updates: A quick refresh of the Sales Cloud V2 Opportunity instantly updates the Net Value and Negotiated Value, reflecting the latest changes made in CPQ.

Handling Complex Products: Configuring Quotes from Sales Cloud V2

While the standard workflow is great for simple product sets, what about complex, configurable products? The integration handles this seamlessly as well, keeping the Sales Cloud V2 Opportunity as the starting point.

For products requiring detailed configuration (like machinery, specialized services, or complex bundles), the process adjusts slightly:

  • Skip the Opportunity Product Entry: You no longer need to add the product directly to the Sales Cloud V2 Opportunity.
  • Launch CPQ for Configuration: Using the External Sales Quote option (as described previously), you initiate the quote in CPQ.
  • Configure and Save: Products are added and configured as required directly within the SAP CPQ interface.
  • Full Data Pushback: When you save the configured quote, the system ensures complete data transfer. The detailed configuration data—including the final products used, quantities, and calculated amounts—is then pushed back and added to the associated Sales Cloud V2 Opportunity.

This capability ensures that whether the product is simple or highly complex, your Sales Cloud V2 Opportunity remains the accurate, single source of truth for the financial and product details of the deal.

Furthermore, if you want to embed the SAP CPQ screen directly in an Opportunity in Sales Cloud V2 using the Mashup Authoring extensibility feature.

 

Key Benefits of This Unified Approach

  • Seamlessly move from Opportunity to Quote and back, eliminating disruptive system-hopping for sales users.
  • Automated data transfer and real-time synchronization ensure consistent, accurate data between Sales Cloud V2 and CPQ, drastically reducing manual errors.
  • Leveraging prebuilt iFlows through SAP Cloud Integration minimizes custom development work, allowing you to deploy and realize benefits much faster.

 

Integration setup:

Before going through steps required to setup the integration between SAP Sales Cloud V2 and SAP CPQ, here are some prerequisites which you must meet:

  1. CPQ Requirement: Must use a CPQ tenant with the Quote 2.0 framework enabled.

  2. Integration Dependency: CPQ integration requires S/4HANA Integration to function (it is delivered for joint use).

  3. Master Data Setup: Complete the Initial Load of Master Data from S/4HANA to Sales Cloud V2, OR update all relevant Sales Cloud V2 External IDs with the S/4HANA System ID reference.

  4. ID Mapping Rule: ID mapping is indirect via S/4HANA. S/4HANA IDs are the primary reference between CPQ and Sales Cloud V2.

  5. Error Warning: Missing external IDs will trigger the error: "Outbound Synchronous request mapping failed."

  6. Configuration Constraint: The Opportunity to External Sales Quote configuration in Sales Cloud V2 must be unique (e.g., cannot configure for both CPQ and S/4HANA simultaneously). Multiple configurations result in the error: "Missing unique configuration for external quote communication."

Configurations required in SAP Sales Cloud:

  • Create Communication systems for S/4HANA & Cloud Integration (CPI connecting to CPQ) systems. Enable Inbound user & outbound communication for CPI system (configure the outbound https host as CPI runtime host).
  • Create a Communication Configuration by copying template “Integrate Opportunity with SAP CPQ”. Use the Cloud integration system name as comm. system.
  • In Properties comm configuration, set the S/4HANA system name
  • Add “Retrieve Document Flow from SAP S/4HANA, SAP ERP, or SAP CPQ” outbound HTTP with API path as runtime endpoint of standard iflow “Retrieve Document Flow from SAP CPQ” of integration package SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 Integration with SAP CPQ from CPI. This outbound configuration will be used to sync the quote data from CPQ to Sales V2. It will be trigger when you refresh the opportunity.
  • Add “Retrieve Follow-Up Quote Details from CPQ” outbound HTTP with API path as runtime endpoint of standard iflow “Retrieve Follow-Up Quote Details from SAP CPQ” of integration package SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 Integration with SAP CPQ from CPI. This outbound configuration will be used to update the follow up document details with CPQ quote.
  • Set the API path for Create Follow-Up Quote in SAP CPQ from Opportunity HTTP outbound with runtime endpoint of standard iflow “Create Follow-Up Quote in SAP CPQ from Opportunity” of integration package SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 Integration with SAP CPQ from CPI. This outbound configuration will be used to trigger the CPQ quote creation from Sales Cloud V2 on click of External CPQ Quote submission.
  • In the inbound configuration, make sure the Update Opportunity with SAP CPQ Quote Details is configured in the communication configuration. This inbound configuration will be used to update the Opportunity with CPQ status, amounts, discounts, etc data.
  • Configure External Link to navigate to SAP CPQ quote screen from Opportunity. For this, set the below:

External Object - Sales Quote

Communication system - CPI system name (created in step 1)

Link - https://<CPQDomain>.cpq.cloud.sap/fed/demo8/cart/edit?cartcompositenumber=${displayId}

Configurations required in SAP Cloud Integration:

  • Use the Cloud Integration standard package SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 Integration with SAP CPQ  to integrate sales quotes between SAP Sales Cloud V2 and SAP CPQ.
  • Below are key interfaces to be configured:

Create Follow-up Quote in SAP CPQ from Opportunity (to create the quote in CPQ)

Retrieve Follow-Up Quote Details from CPQ (to update the follow-up document with quote id from CPQ)

Retrieve Document Flow from CPQ (to update the opportunity with Quote ID, set primary quote)

Update Opportunity with SAP CPQ Quote Details (to update opportunity with CPQ quote data like negotiation amount, discounts, etc when the quote is saved or submitted)

Additionally, if you are using subscription products in opportunity Sales Cloud V2, then use Update Subscription Product Fields in SAP CPQ Quote to sync the quote updates from CPQ to Sales Cloud.

  • Configure the Value Mapping with respective processing statuses, rejection statuses, owner names between CPQ and Sales Cloud V2 systems.

Configurations required in SAP CPQ:

  • Subscribe to Quote events to update the Sales Cloud opportunity with Quote data. You can use QuoteEvent (OnSaveAction) to trigger Cloud integration iflow Update Opportunity with SAP CPQ Quote Details.
  • If directly login is required with SSO, enable SSO with federation settings between both Sales cloud v2 and CPQ to be setup using SAP Cloud Identity Authentication Service in BTP.

References links:

Integrate Master data from S/4HANA to SAP CPQ Quote 2.0

Integrate Master data from S/4HANA to SAP Sales Cloud V2

Quote integration between SAP CPQ and Sales Cloud V2

Enable SSO in SAP CPQ

Enable SSO in Sales Cloud V2

the RealTimeSync is a special case where instead of the CIS pulling the data from SF, one SCIM dataset is sent to the SF source system in CIS

To your point 1. "targetUrl"
The DEFAULT targetURL is the one listed under the URL Parameter of the Application in CIS
you can change this for all there
or
change it for some in the transformation



To the second point, listing the "Login Name" as a potential identifier during the login, that is a GLOBAL CIS tenant setting under CIS > Applications & Resources > Tenant Settings > Authentication > Logon Alias

You disable this for ALL users, not just onboardees

Best is to keep it in place as is

HTH
Peter

entry.title: Re: CAP Multitenancy: Connectivity Service returns 401 in...
entry.content:
I managed to resolve the issue. It was not related to MTA or provisioning, but to the mtx/sidecar package.json. 

In a CAP multitenant setup, Connectivity must be explicitly declared in the sidecar. If it is missing, token retrieval fails with 401 invalid_client, even though the service is bound and Destination works.

{
  "cds": {
    "requires": {
      "destinations": true,
      "connectivity": true
    }
  }
}

 After redeploy, the issue was resolved.

entry.title: Re: BW knowledge required for BDC?
entry.content:
Hi LGarcia,

BW is an optional component in the SAP Business Data Cloud landscape. Customers who already run SAP BW can add it to their BDC formation so that they can use their BW data to for machine learning and AI projects. So I'd say you need detailed BW knowledge only if you want to work on a project where BW will be a key part of the overall solution. For projects where BW is not included or if you are not responsible for its integration to BDC, you do not need BW knowledge.

entry.title: Quantity Distribution settings
entry.content:

Best regards,

Lars

entry.title: Re: SAP S/4HANA Cloud ERP (public) - Nielsen ID for Busin...
entry.content:
Dear @KatjaWa,

In Public Cloud the Nielsen Indicator is a standard marketing attribute in Business Partner data BUT SAP currently does not provide an SSCUI in CBC to maintain the Nielsen ID catalog / value help which is why your F4 help is empty

More details from SAP Community:

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/about-customer-master-data/qaq-p/12370090

What you can do instead in Public Cloud (safe options / recommended workaround):

1.Use a custom field instead of the standard Nielsen field:

  • Create a custom field on Business Partner in Custom Fields app
  • Use field type Code List so you get your own maintained value help or Text if you don’t need validation

 

  • In your ECC to Public Cloud replication mapping, map ECC Nielsen value into that custom field

Summary: This is the cleanest approach in Public Cloud when SAP doesn’t expose configuration for a standard value list

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: From PI/PO to SAP Edge Integration Cell: Initial Sizing Approach and Planning for HA/Non-HA Setup
entry.content:
SAP Edge Integration Cell- Sizing Approach 

Planning the migration from SAP PI/PO to the SAP Integration Suite requires accurate infrastructure sizing for the Edge Integration Cell.

In this post, I demonstrate a practical sizing approach by applying the official Sizing Guide to a real-world scenario. By analyzing PI/PO Message Performance, this guide helps you determine the necessary hardware resources to ensure a stable foundation for your migration to SAP Edge Integration Cell.  Furthermore, I will outline the key differences between High Availability (HA) and Non-HA setups, highlighting the critical factors you need to consider when selecting this two setups. 

   

1.      Input for Sizing – Business Throughput

Business Throughput is the number of business transactions or messages an SAP system processes within a given time, usually specified as messages or transactions per hour or second. It is a key metric in sizing because it determines the necessary CPU, memory, and other resources to handle the expected workload effectively.

Sizing with Business Throughput involves converting hourly throughput to messages per second to account for load distribution and peak times. SAP uses benchmarks like SAPS (SAP Application Performance Standard) to translate business throughput into hardware requirements.

In summary: Business Throughput quantifies the expected transactional load and is the foundation for planning the infrastructure capacity to ensure optimal SAP system performance and stability.

 

In our case, we calculate the SAP PI/PO Business Throughput, which measures the volume of messages or transactions processed by the Process Integration and Process Orchestration system within a defined timeframe. This calculation is essential for sizing the infrastructure to support the expected load and ensure optimal system performance.

1.1. Scope

The following components of the EIC will be considered for sizing:

  • Worker: Executes integration flows within the Integration Suite runtime, built on Apache Camel. Responsible for both synchronous and asynchronous message processing.
  • Policy Engine: Envoy-based runtime with SAP-specific extensions, enforces policies such as traffic management and security for API proxies.
  • PostgreSQL Database: Relational database system for storing structured metadata and logging data generated during integration scenarios.
  • Redis: In-memory data store used primarily for caching and storing operational data, including support for API traffic management policies.
  • Message Service: Implements asynchronous integration patterns using the JMS protocol and manages local event processing.

 

2.      Required input factors 

The following factor will be required:

  • Number of messages per second
  • Size of average payload
  • Complexity of Integration flow

 

Number of messages per second

When determining the number of messages per second for sizing purposes, it is important to clarify and standardize the assumptions:

  • The “number of messages per second” should refer to the maximum throughput during peak periods, not an average across the year.​
  • Identify the peak time range (for example, analyze which month has the highest message volume). Subsequently, break down the peak month to the number of messages per second and consider the average payload size for that period.
  • When calculating, consider the following questions:
    • Should weekends be included in the calculation, or is message traffic significantly lower?
    • Should sizing be based on 24-hour operation, or does your existing PI/PO system operate during defined business hours only (e.g., 8 hours per day)?

This approach ensures that capacity is planned according to realistic worst-case load, which is recommended to guarantee stable system performance even during short-lasting throughput peaks

3.      Delivered Messages statistics- Performance Monitoring

Crucial Assumption- Peak Period:

For the analysis and sizing calculation, message statistics tables were directly extracted from SAP PI/PO Performance Monitoring. The available week of message data was chosen as the reference peak period. Because only one week of message statistics was available at the time of analysis, all sizing calculations are based on this week—used here as the reference "peak period."

Going this approach because possible higher peaks is not yet accessible.

By using this, the system is planned to handle at least the highest observed workload, safeguarding against typical peak scenarios.​

To make the evaluation as clear and practical as possible, the message data was systematically split into three tables:

  1. An All Messages Statistics Table capturing all messages from the week, combining both synchronous (real-time) and asynchronous (delayed/queued) communications.
  2. A Synchronous Messages Statistics Table including only real-time message exchanges, where instant system-to-system response is required.
  3. An Asynchronous Message Statistics Table gathering messages processed without immediate answers, reflecting queued or scheduled processes.

For each of these datasets and every reviewed time interval, two main metrics are calculated:

Average payload size: Indicates the typical data volume per message, usually in kilobytes or megabytes.

Average number of messages per second: Shows the sustained rate at which the system processes messages.

By distinguishing between message types and quantifying peak load figures, the resource requirements for both synchronous and asynchronous scenarios can be more accurately determined.The ultimate goal is to ensure that system capacity meets actual business needs even during the busiest periods.

3.1. All Messages Statistics Table including Sync and Async-Complex

 

a.All Messages Statistics Table -Average payload size

 

b.  All Messages Statistics Table - Message per second

 

3.2 Synchronous Statistics Messages Table

a. Synchronous Statistics Message Table - Average payload size

 

 

b. Synchronous Statistics Message Table - Message per second

 

3.3 Asynchronous Statistics Messages Table

 

a. Asynchronous Message Table - Average payload size

 

b. Asynchronous Message Table - Message per second

 

 

4. Sizing Approach for Worker (Complex Integration Flow)

For sizing the Worker component, all calculations are carried out using complex integration flows. Separating simple from complex flows in real-world systems is often very time-consuming and difficult because this distinction is usually not visible in the message logs.

 

Furthermore, experience and SAP guidelines show that the actual difference in sizing results between simple and complex flows is not significant. For simplicity and to avoid unnecessary complexity, we base all calculations on complex flows. This guarantees that the system is sufficiently dimensioned for any type of integration workload.

 

SAP Application Performance Standard (SAPS)

The actual sizing is performed using the SAP Application Performance Standard (SAPS).

For all worker-related calculations in this guide, the rule is applied that 1 CPU core equals roughly 1400 SAPS.

4.1. Synchronous - Complex Integration Flows

Input

  1. Average Payload size for Synchronous -Complex Integration Flow: 12,50KB
  2. Throughput = 0,0077 messages per seconds

Applying linear ratio for payload size

If your actual average payload size or message throughput differs from the values in the predefined table below—which lists CPU and memory requirements for specific throughput and payload sizes—you should use linear scaling to estimate the required resources.

Steps to apply linear scaling:

  1. Identify the closest payload size in the reference table that is nearest to your actual average payload size.
    • This closest size is called the reference payload size.

  2. Calculate the scaled message throughput using:

     

  3. Round the scaled message throughput number to the nearest whole number.

  4. Use the CPU, memory, and instance recommendations from the table for the reference payload size and this scaled message rate to size your system.

 

 

Determined results

12,5KB/100 * 0,0077= 0,00096 scaled messages per second

 

Correspond to the table below

CPU

2800 SAPS = 2CPU  

// (reminder:1400 SAPS = 1CPU)

4.2.  Asynchronous- Complex Integration Flows( Variant 2)

 

Input

  1. Average Payload size for Asynchronous -Complex Integration Flow(Variant 2): 668,67KB
  2. Throughput = 0,56 messages per seconds

5.      Message Service Tier for Asynchronous Messages

For Message Service Tier selection, message throughput usually isn't the deciding factor—the number of required JMS queues and general storage are far more critical. You should carefully review your scenarios to determine how many queues you need, consider the asynchronous interface communications and pipeline concepts for Integration Suite.

 

Once you've selected a tier, you should test and validate if your throughput matches your selected message service tier.

 

Input

  1. Average Payload size for asynchronous -Complex Integration Flow: 668,67KB
  2. Throughput = 0,56 messages per seconds

 

668,67KB/1024 * 0,56= 0,36 scaled messages per second for 1MB payload size

 

 

For production setups, it is recommended to consider Message Service Tier 250 or higher.

7.      Database Sizing (PostgreSQL)

7.1. Storage

Input

  • Total messages for 1 week: 345,295 messages
  • Retention period: 30 days. Therefore, the number of messages per month is calculated as 345,295 * 4 = 1,381,180 messages.
  • Approximate disk space: 13.81 GB, rounded up to 15 GB.

 

 

Determined results

 

This calculation assumes message logging at the INFO level. TRACE-level logging or additional datastore usage could increase storage needs by ~50%.

Additional factors like MPL attachments, trace data, general overhead, datastore entries, and message store entries also consume storage.

 

For reliability, size for at least 32 GB -->>ideally 64 GB—a low-cost safeguard.

 

Disk Space (Volume)

9.      Sizing Output for EIC

Why do we start with the Non-HA Baseline? We start our calculation with the smallest standard configuration: the Non-High Availability (Non-HA) setup.

In our specific example, the existing PI/PO system has very low message traffic. Due to this low workload, we anticipate that the SAP Edge Integration Cell will not require extensive hardware resources.

At this step, we have not yet decided if the final SAP EIC will be an HA or Non-HA setup. Therefore, we use this minimum baseline as a starting point. Then, we add our specific calculated workload (the "Delta") to it.

Finally, after seeing the total requirements, we compare the results against the HA and Non-HA setups to make a final conclusion

9.4.      Summary and Conclusion 

The summary of the sizing results for SAP Edge Integration Cell is based on the final table of the document. The recommended sizing for the non-HA setup amounts to 13 CPU and 50.5 GiB of memory for all EIC components, with a mandatory storage requirement of at least 101 GB and optionally up to 71 GB more. For the external database/store components, PostgreSQL is specified with 1 CPU, 2 GB RAM, and 64 GB storage, and Redis with 1 CPU and 1 GB RAM. These total values are derived from summing the individual components and form the basis for technical infrastructure planning.

The calculation approach was based on real peak load data from one observed week, separating synchronous and asynchronous message types to assess their maximum resource requirements independently. By using these peak values, the sizing ensures the system capacity is designed to handle actual business throughput during the busiest periods, following SAP’s best-practice. The result shows that the calculated values are clearly above the minimum requirement for a non-HA system but do not reach the requirements for an HA setup (which would require at least 20 CPU, 64 GiB RAM, and 204 GiB storage)

Difference between HA and non-HA Setup 

The non-HA sizing results for SAP Edge Integration Cell show that with 13 CPUs, 50.5 GiB RAM, and at least 101 GB of storage, the setup exceeds the minimum required for non-HA, but it is still below the requirements for a high-availability (HA) setup, which needs 20 CPUs, 64 GiB RAM, and 204 GB of storage. External datastores and optional components are not included in these figures.

A non-HA setup typically operates around 40 pods on one or two worker nodes. An HA setup runs approximately 80 to 90 pods and is designed to provide higher availability and failover capabilities, especially for the Message Service, which is primarily used for asynchronous scenarios and JMS queues. In non-HA, the Message Service runs as a single instance; in HA, it operates with two replicas and an additional monitoring pod so that if one instance fails, the other can take over, significantly reducing interruptions in JMS-based processing.

The Message Service is a critical component, as it manages asynchronous messages and internal system events. In a non-HA environment, this service exists as a single instance; if it fails, all integration flows using JMS queues fail during the downtime, while other integration flows without JMS are not affected. During this period, deployments and undeployments of artifacts on the EIC also fail, and new Message Processing Logs (MPLs) are no longer written to the database.

Once the Message Service in a non-HA environment is available again, all previously persisted messages remain and will be reprocessed, as long as the underlying persistence volume has not been deleted or replaced. However, if the EIC – including the Message Service – is uninstalled and reinstalled, all queues and messages within them will be lost, since the components are rebuilt from scratch.

An HA deployment runs at least two replicas of the Message Service along with a monitoring pod. This setup enables immediate failover: if one replica fails, the second takes over with minimal interruption, allowing JMS-based integration flows to continue with little or no downtime. Upscale activities on the Message Service will always result in a brief downtime, but in an HA setup this disruption is much shorter than when operating with a single instance in non-HA mode.

Key Aspect for Message Service :

  • What happens to messages if the Message Service fails in a non-HA setup?

For the duration of the downtime the following things will happen: All Integration Flows that use JMS Queues will fail, other IFlows are not affected. All (un-)deployments of artefacts onto EIC fail. No MPLs will be written to the DB anymore.

 

  • Are messages in the queue lost, and can they be processed again when the Message Service is restarted?

Once the Message Service is up again/has restarted all previously stored messages are retained and will get processed again as long as the underlying Persistent Volume has not been wiped out. If EIC has been uninstalled and re-installed again, the Message Service also gets deleted completely --> all queues and messages are lost.

 

  • How much downtime do we risk if we need to scale up the Message Service with only one instance in non-HA?

The upscale activity always causes a downtime (usually very short - less than a minute or a few minutes) - also in HA mode.

  • Additional Consideration:
    • The Storage Class must be configured as Block Storage or iSCSI to ensure stable processing of the critical Message Service

HA setup for production 

Based on the sizing analysis conducted, I recommend deploying a High Availability (HA) setup with 3 worker nodes for both DEV/TEST and PROD.

Although the HA setup requires higher resources (20 CPUs and 64 GiB RAM) compared to the calculated non-HA requirements (13 CPUs and 50.5 GiB RAM), the delta of 7 CPUs is negligible compared to the outage risks of a non-redundant infrastructure. Crucially, it is not possible to switch from Non-HA to HA without completely redeploying the Edge Integration Cell.

Furthermore, a consistent HA setup across DEV/TEST and PROD eliminates transport errors and guarantees system consistency across all landscapes.

Recommended HA Configuration:

  • 3 Worker Nodes with a total of 20 CPUs and 64 GiB RAM
  • Message Service with 2 Replicas + Monitoring Pod for JMS High Availability
  • Block Storage or iSCSI for Persistent Volumes (204 GB)
  • PostgreSQL or HANA as an external database with HA replication
  • Starting directly with HA prevents future migrations and data loss

entry.title: Re: Display-Only Authorization for Manage Tax Rates & Sal...
entry.content:
Hi @Zong ,

It's possible, you can configure display-only access for the Manage Tax Rates and Manage Sales Prices apps in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition by adjusting the business roles and catalogs. SAP does not provide a dedicated "read-only" app variant, but you can restrict authorizations at the catalog level so users can only view condition records without being able to create, edit, or delete them.
Business Roles: Access is controlled through business roles that bundle business catalogs.
Business Catalogs: Each catalog defines what actions (create, edit, display) are possible in an app.
Restrictions: Within catalogs, you can apply restrictions to limit actions to "Display" only.

entry.title: EWM Outbound Delivery Goods Issue Dump MOVE_CAST_ERROR in /SCWM/PRDO
entry.content:
Problem
While posting Goods Issue for an outbound delivery order in SAP EWM, the system terminates with an ABAP dump.

Error details

  • Runtime error: MOVE_CAST_ERROR
  • Exception: CX_SY_MOVE_CAST_ERROR
  • Program: /SCWM/CL_IM_DLV_PPF_SCHED=====CP
  • Method: SCHED_TU_CREATION
  • Component: SCM-EWM-DLP

The dump occurs when saving the delivery or posting Goods Issue via /SCWM/PRDO.
The failure happens during standard scheduling logic for TU creation.

At first glance, this looks like a code defect.
The dump points to a failed cast between delivery header classes.
No relevant SAP Notes appear when searching by class or method.

Root cause
The issue is caused by incorrect configuration of the action profile assigned to the outbound delivery document type.

Solution

Check the outbound delivery customizing.

Path

SIMG> SCM Extended Warehouse Management > Extended Warehouse Management > Goods Issue Process > Outbound Delivery > Define Document Types for Outbound Delivery Process

SIMG > Navigation Path

Steps

  • Locate the entry for Document Category FDO
  • Select the outbound delivery document type
  • Verify the assigned action profile
  • Correct the action profile if it is inconsistent

Once the action profile is corrected, Goods Issue posting works without dump.

Practical note
In our case, the issue was initially analyzed as a technical defect due to the dump signature.
Only after reviewing delivery configuration did the root cause become clear.
This experience within the ALTZEN team reinforced how tightly EWM runtime logic depends on correct PPF configuration.

SAP Reference
SAP has documented this behavior in KBA 3685116.
note - 3685116

entry.title: Behind the Curtains - what's new about Maintenance Certificates
entry.content:
Blog posts often highlight changes that are severely impacting your business if you do not read the documentation or release notes thoroughly (and let's be honest - who has time for that?!). But not this time – relax, there’s no immediate call to action and no big changes impacting your daily business. This is all about a small improvement that highlights SAP’s ongoing push for automation and simplification of processes. And even more: It's one puzzle piece to reduce your dependency of SAP Solution Manager on your journey to SAP Cloud ALM. 

Maintenance Certificates are a crucial safety mechanism that ensures your system is part of a valid maintenance contract, allowing SAP to provide proper support. Until now, it was your responsibility to ensure that the certificate was properly renewed and distributed to the SAP system. Tools like SAP Solution Manager offered automation for this, but it was still a customer obligation to make sure the process was in place. 

Now, upfront distribution is not required anymore, and the eligibility check is fully automated. Here’s how it works: 

  1. One central SAP Host Agent in customer landscape is configured to communicate with SAP Support Backbone. 
  2. SAP Host Agents of other systems communicate via the central SAP Host Agent. 
  3. The SAP Support Backbone holds the information about the valid certificates which is automatically requested via the Host Agent mechanism if needed. 

And the best part? After an initial configuration of the federated SAP Host Agent Setup you do not need to worry about License Management anymore! This functionality is delivered via (minimum) SPAM version 91 that is all part of Software Logistics (SL) Toolset 1.0 SPS 45, and requires minimum SAP Host Agent version 67. You can find more information on the necessary configuration steps for SAP Host Agent here:  SAP Host Agent | SAP Help Portal 

Of course, there’s a fallback solution: If the automated process is not set up, you can still manually request a valid maintenance certificate in the SAP Support Portal and install it manually in the system or distribute it via SAP Focused Run or via SAP Solution Manager (please keep in mind that mainstream maintenance for SAP Solution Manager 7.2 is only available until the end of 2027). 

For the Tech-Savvy: 

The entire flow is a collaboration between License Management (transaction SLICENSE), SPAM, and SAP Host Agent. It is used also by Software Update Manager (SUM). All the tools are combined in the SL Toolset. 

If you encounter any issues, please open an incident under component SV-SMG-LIC. Feel free to ask questions below this post and let us know what you think!

entry.title: Re: Customer Classification setup to be captured in a TR
entry.content:
Hi @MuraliRN ,

The reason TCode CL02 and CT04 don’t prompt for a TR. CL02 (Class maintenance) and CT04 (Characteristic maintenance) are considered master data maintenance transactions, not configuration.
Master data changes (like creating or editing classes/characteristics) are stored directly in tables and do not trigger transport requests automatically. That’s why you don’t see the TR popup when saving.

How to capture these changes in a Transport Request
Since you want to move this setup across systems (e.g., from Dev → QA → Prod), you need to use transport tools for master data. Use Transaction R3TR / Transport Organizer. Go to SE10/SE09 and create a transport request manually. Then include the relevant objects (characteristics and classes). Transaction SCM or SCC1 won’t help here because those are for client copy. Instead, you need Transaction CTMC (Transport Classes) → allows you to select classes and assign them to a TR. Transaction CTMS (Transport Characteristics) → same for characteristics.

The alternative way to do this is, Use Transaction SE03 → Object Directory → Transport Object Types.
Select object type KLAH (Class) or CABN (Characteristic). Assign them to a transport request.

Program-based method, SAP provides reports like RSTRANSP or R3TR object entries for characteristics/classes. You can run program RDDIMPDP or use R3TR CHAR CABN <char_name> to include them in TR.

entry.title: Re: Customer expected price condition type EDI1
entry.content:
Hi @KVKUMAR ,

That's correct, this is standard behavior. The condition type EDI1 (Customer Expected Price) is a statistical condition in SAP. It does not replace the actual pricing condition (like PPR0). The "Accept customer price" action in the Fiori app only acknowledges the discrepancy but does not overwrite the system-calculated price. If you want to use the customer’s expected price as the actual price, you must adjust the pricing manually or configure a custom routine to copy EDI1 into the main price condition.

The reason EDI1 behaves this way because, EDI1 is statistical: SAP defines EDI1 (expected gross price) and EDI2 (expected net price) as statistical conditions. They are used to capture what the customer sent in their EDI order, but they don’t determine the final billing price. The system compares EDI1 against your calculated price (e.g., PPR0). If there’s a difference, the document is flagged as incomplete so you can review it.

Fiori "Accept customer price": This button acknowledges the customer’s expected price in the workflow but does not automatically replace the system price. It’s designed to help avoid disputes, not to override pricing logic
You’re not missing a setting—EDI1 is not meant to overwrite actual pricing. If your business requires that behavior, you’ll need a custom enhancement or manual intervention. Would you like me to walk you through how to configure an alternative calculation routine so that EDI1 can replace PPR0 automatically, or would you prefer to explore tolerance-based acceptance where small differences are auto-approved? configure alternative calculation routine for EDI1, set tolerance checks for customer expected price
